title: English (1749) Challoner DRV New Testament
description:
The Challoner Douay-Rheims Version (DRV) New Testament, initially revised by Richard Challoner in 1749, is a significant development in English Bible translations. This work involved revising the original Douay-Rheims Bible, first published by the English College at Douay in 1609, to modernize and correct it according to the Clementine Edition of the Scriptures. It also included annotations to address difficulties in understanding Holy Writ. The revision history of the Challoner DRV includes:

1749: The first revision of the New Testament by Challoner, incorporating changes from the 1738 edition (also by Richard Challoner and Francis Blyth).
1750: The first revision of the Old Testament (in two volumes) and the second revision of the New Testament (in one volume).
1752: The third revision of the New Testament (in two volumes).
1763 - 1764: The second revision of the Old Testament (in four volumes).
1764: The fourth revision of the New Testament.
1772: The fifth revision of the New Testament.
1790: The first American edition based on Challoner's second edition (1763-64) was published in Philadelphia by Carey, Stewart & Co.
1796: Another edition was published in Edinburgh by John Moir.
1942: A New York edition by The Douay Bible House, using the 1752 revision by Dr. Challoner.

The 1942 edition is noted for being commended by the Pope as the best text in the American tradition. Challoner's revisions of the Douay-Rheims Bible played a crucial role in making this translation more accessible and understandable to English-speaking Catholics, ensuring its continued use and significance in religious studies and practices.
